title: Wrong trie root of block 4651798
body:
This error has unfortunately  replicated itself 9 times within the past 13 hours for the same block number:

`Wrong trie root of block 4651798: df42b15198499f9415e7cf0938f315c11283f8b247448a649b0620b659a658e5, expected (from header): 8662298f761a4e7b0d5888e3d6ff9a02a82ac8121d1f0a3f51503ffea144c3f9. Block hash: c9cbd5858dc7f22d1be0617d12538a9af048cb0db7897b73c050962029511d1d`

Is there anyway to bypass or force a correct block hash for block **4651798**? 

Incidentally, it appears similar to [issue 2611](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/issues/2611) which I believe was fixed with an update in September 2021. 

### System information

Erigon version: v2022.01.01 **AND** v2021.12.03

OS & Version: Ubuntu 20.04.3 LTS (GNU/Linux 5.4.0-94-generic x86_64)

Commit hashes : db7fa3d0ed0758fdca29efd337c85200a290becf **AND**  748abd39f68b44408555dc6eb6648999f6b5a7ad

### Expected behaviour
Block and hash should be processed correctly

### Actual behaviour
Whenever Erigon reaches block **4651798** is does a forced restart and unwinds all the transactions. 

This seems to be a continuous error loop because it's happened 9 times in the past 13 hours.

### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
**Use-case:** Deploying Erigon with Lighthouse for proof-of-stake on the Ethereum main net. 

This error occurred on a fresh install on new Ubuntu 20.04 server.  Below is how we configure and launch Erigon:

**/etc/systemd/system/eth1-erigon.service**

```
[Unit]
Description    = Erigon ETH1 Execution Client service
Wants            = network-online.target
After              = network-online.target 
Requires        = erigon-rpcdaemon.service

[Service]
Type            = simple
User            = $USER
ExecStart       = $HOME/erigon/build/bin/erigon --datadir /var/lib/erigon --chain mainnet --private.api.addr=localhost:9089 --metrics --pprof --prune htc --prune.r.before=11184524
Restart         = on-failure
RestartSec      = 3
KillSignal      = SIGINT
TimeoutStopSec  = 5

[Install]
WantedBy    = multi-user.target
```

Thought this issue resolved on its own. But it repeated itself again, so will reopen.

Any help or guidance from the devs @AskAlexSharov @AlexeyAkhunov would be humbly appreciated

I see `from=2325899 to=4651798` Erigon doesn't work this way - it must jump from 0 to latest block in 1 hope during genesis sync. 
So: 
- Or you have bad internet and stage_bodies not able to download block bodies by timeout - and Erigon moves to another stages.
- Or we have bug in stage_bodies which by some reason can't utilize good internet connection (we have 1 report about slow stage_bodies).

@AskAlexSharov appreciate  your feedback.

* Doubt it's internet. The box is connected to a managed switch with Gigabit fiber + automatic failover to ~500mbps cable internet as a backup. The Lighthouse consensus client hummed along without any issues.  Also very minimal traffic on this connection at time of failures (failures started at 02:00 hours) 

* The posted output of `journalctl -fu eth1-erigon` was just a 4 minute snapshot of logs after running 24 hours straight. And ~ 1 hour after giving  the error on its 8th pass at block 4651798. It first reached block 4651798 at around 12 hours.  Then it clocked in an additional 13 hours of unwinding and retrying that block 9 times

Would us posting a longer log timeframe help any?

Totally understand your team is swamped, but if we can get an idea of the fix applied in issue https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/issues/2611 we can try to do a pull request with a fix -- although we are not Go developers -- as we are desperate to get this functioning.

**Update:**
Or as a short term, in-house hack Is there anyway for us to manually code in the correct block hash for block 4651798?

You are now in beginning of sync. I advise you just remove Erigon folder, switch to v2021.12.03 and try again. While we investigating. Because we can reproduce the problem - so, don't need much debug from you now.

Will hold off on reverting as we first noticed the error while running v2021.12.03. 

After running v2021.12.03 for 17 hours, we upgraded to v2022.01.01 and error persisted over the next 7 to 8 hours.
optimistically closing this issue. if it's still a problem - feel free to re-open
